title: Inconsistent customer service
text: I am giving the 3 stars review because while flight itself was short and unremarkable, but the customer service surrounding was not good. First, make sure you read a small print of your tickets. They charge extra fee, if you do not come with the downloaded online check-in. We were having trouble getting check in online, so the customer service gave us a break. However, here where inconsistency were: on the flight Athens-Santorini we got free baggage check in. On the flight back (with the same bags) we were told that we had to pay for the checked in baggage and could not take them with us. While we were standing on the security line (which was very chaotic) I noticed people with bags, which were the same size as ours and even bigger and heavier. They all got in and got they bags taken for check in for free while we boarding. It gave me impression that check in might be a subject to the agent's mood (the guy who was doing our check in on the Santorini-Athens flight was unpleasant to everyone in that line).

title: Drinks on the sunset
text: Had drinks with the sunset in this place. The drinks were pretty good (I had sangria) and the view was great. Waiters are nice and the owner, Nick, was pretty chatty. Nice atmosphere. A great stop to make.

title: Great way to spend a day
text: This tour honestly exceeded expectations. All of us on our small group shared that notion (the group was only 6 people). You can check the stops on the tour description they give on this website. Unlike other tours I've been to, this one was quite well paced and relaxing. We met our guide Nicholas at the Thira bus station, he already had a sign with our names on it. He was most gracious host and created fun atmosphere. He seemed as a person who is genially proud of this place and strove to share it with us. He also was super helpful picking angles for photos and offered to take pictures. The only thing I wished for is that he had a microphone, because with roads being quite rocky, sometimes there are a lot of rattle and it is hard to hear what guide was saying. Regardless, it was great time. Highly recommend. And thank you Nicholas!
place: Santorini Highlights Tour with Wine Tasting from Fira (small group up to 10)

title: Adorable, comfortable and affordable
text:
We stayed there for only three nights and I wish it was more. Location is super convenient: in a two min walk from the beach and restaurants and shops; a bus to the Thira is across the street. The hotel also has a pool and bar, where you can get drinks and food. I had breakfast there: Greek yogurt with fruits and it was very good. They provide free towels for the beach too. The building itself is super cute. Rooms
were clean and comfy. I think all of them have balconies. Things I was not prepared for were: roosters early in morning and local dogs, who made quite a noise as well. So, if you are a light sleeper, get yourself ear plugs. The airport is close enough too and sometimes you can hear them pass by, but this is true for the entire village of Kamari. Staff at the hotel is beyond friendly and helpful. Very lovely people.

title: Great views, average tour
text: The temple and surroundings are breathtaking. The tour itself is average at best. The information that was provided was mostly basic (with the exception of history of the temple). I would treat this tour as a form of transportation to the temple and back.
place: Cape Sounion and Temple of Poseidon Half-Day Trip from Athens

title: Never cease to amaze
text: This was my time here and I could not wait to get there. It is a magnificent creation that withstood thousands of years. If you are traveling at the end of the tourist season, you do not need to worry about major crowds (they still be there, but not as much). If you are traveling during hot time of the year, then get there earlier. We got a guide who was soliciting clients at the gate and paid 30 euros for entry and tour (entry itself is 20 euro). The tour was uneven in a quality: the guide was not taking us up to the temple itself, but she talked about history of Athens and building of the temple. However, in my opinion it went on too long. Enjoy the grounds and roam around. Pro tip: find out when the cruise ships come into town: on those days the lines are hours long.

title: Beautiful
text: The estate is located a bit far away from the main action, however it totally worth the drive. A copy of a British architecture with a Czech flare. It was quiet and not overrun by tourists. Check out the yard and gardens.

title: A nice place to take a break while sightseeing
text: It is located in what seems to be a newer part of the city. It looks unassuming from outside, but it is really good. Inside you can pick from several restaurants. I had arctic char from Skal and it was delicious. Washed it down with some Icelandic ale. Perfect lunch. Place provides you with a welcoming break from busy day of sightseeing.

title: You got to be nature fanatic
text: It is a tiny island in the bay. You got to take a little boat to get there (5 min ride). The island itself has almost nothing on it, except a several small houses, which were a part of a farm once upon a time. There is nothing to do. You got to be nature fanatic or photo enthusiast to truly enjoy it. It is not worth the time.

title: Great food with a personal touch
text: Had a fish and chips dinner there: fresh and delicious! The place is tiny, but totally worth the visit. It would be great for either lunch or light dinner. The staff was super friendly (which seems to be a trend in Iceland). Prices are quite affordable.

title: My first try of Icelandic food
text: Visited it on the first day in Reykjavik. They served plates of samples of typical Icelandic dishes. I got to admit I had mixed experience: some I really enjoyed and some not so much. However, if you are food-adventurous you should try it. Location is great (across the Halgrimskirja).

title: A great place to have breakfast
text: We had breakfast in this place twice (our hotel was nearby): friendly staff, delicious food, cute decor, and reasonable prices. What else do you need? Tea was good and my friend loved the coffee. They also make croissants on the premises and they was wonderful!

title: Simple and small
text: The exhibit is tiny. It might be a good place to visit with kids, as it is small enough for them to handle and contains enough information for them to process about early Icelandic history.

title: Learn about Icelandic history here
text: The open air museum is a collection of houses that were native to Iceland. They have costumed guides telling you about life in Iceland for the past 300 years. The houses actually from the different time periods, so visitors can see the progression. t is a bit tricky to get to without a car, however, not impossible. Got there on a city bus.

title: Great, great and great
text: I never thought I will find great crepe place in Iceland. However, Eldur is awesome. Out of 4 days my friend and I spent in the city, we went 3 times. Crepes were delicious! That is all that needs to be said.

title: Great photo op
text: This church is a major symbol of the city. Can't say you visited Reykjavik without taking a picture with it. Inside it is pretty austere. Be mindful that it is a functioning church and there are hours when it is closed for tourists.

title: A nice walk by the water
text: It was a bit disappointing as I sort of expected more. However, the weather was nice, sun was shining bright and it was a nice walk to take from Harpa further down by the shore.

title: One of the main places to visit in Reykjavik
text: It is a lovely place to visit on a rainy day. Most of it's exhibits are dedicated to different species and areas native to Iceland. This could be fun for kids (especially the ice cave). The show in the Planetarium was amazing! If you are not interested in the exhibit dedicated to the nature, you can buy a ticket to Planetarium only. They show two short films about auroras. It worth the time and money. Afterwards, make your way to the observation deck (you will see entire city) and top it off with the visit to the rotating restaurant on the top. We had dinner and drinks there while enjoying the view. Food was awesome and quite affordable. Tip: there is a free shuttle to the museum from the Harpa.

title: Adorable
text: Visited it during the cherry blossoms week. However, even without the cherry blossoms the garden is beautiful. It's location is sort unassuming, but once inside you will see the carefully planned garden, with paths, little hidden temple, bridges, statues and ponds. Requires a small entry fee.

title: A war museum with a purpose
text: This is a meticulously gathered war memorabilia collection that serves one purpose: to present certain point of view. The place is full of artifacts, photos, diagrams, facts. And while I am always interested in learning how different cultures/countries see the worlds events that many others were involved, this exhibit seemed to lacking some self-awareness. It skillfully avoided "bumpy" parts of the Japan's military history. Unless, you are an absolute fan of military histories (regardless of how they presented) this museum does not worth the admission price.

title: A bustling and beautiful
text: I visited this place during the Cherry Blossoms week and it was fantastic. The large yard of the shrine is full of cherry trees, which created added an extra beauty factor to the shrine. The complex is located in a middle of a bustling neighborhood, so you will hit a few marks that day just by visiting this shrine. There were also different activities going on in the yard. I am not sure if it was because of the Golden week or it is a normal occurrence for the temple, but it worth checking out. I saw a tea ceremony performed for the viewers in the yard. You will need to pay money to sit close, but I saw it just by standing nearby. The entry is free. But there are a couple attractions you will have to pay money to enter. I would skip the Yushukan Museum, unless you are a military history fan.

title: a decent way to spend a day
text: Booked a tour via this website. The reviews seemed to be good and overall tour met the expectations. It started a bit chaotic. First, my confirmation email said that pick up was BY the hotel. It did not mention that you actually have to go INTO hotel, find their counter and register. They put workers in the main area of the hotel lobby to direct travelers to the counter. The scene was chaotic, people were confused on what to do, and workers were running around trying to direct everyone to the correct place and rushing those whose tours were about to leave through the registration counters. It takes some time to get to the second pick up point, so I would recommend to stock up on snacks and water (they allow that on the bus). Our guide was super nice and attentive, but suffered the affliction of many tour guides: talking a lot about where Tokyoties shop, go to restaurants, etc. and not presenting enough history. She gave us some details about each of our stops, but I wish tour would include more in depth narration about history, significance and tradition represented in each place. Macha tea prep ceremony and temples were great and lunch that they provided was very tasty. I thought that the last stop at Enoshima was kind of unnecessary: we were there during the later part of the day, and since it was March, it was really cold on the seaside. Moreover, this place would require at least 2-2.5 hours to explore re and we only had an hour. So, this stop would make more sense during warmer time of the year. I'd rather we spent more time on the previous stops or someplace else than on Enoshima. We also end up sitting in traffic and got back about 1.5 hour later. Overall, I thought it was worth the money I spent, because they took me to places I would not go by myself.

title: Interesting, but something is missing
text: As a museum fanatic I make a point of visiting at least one museum in every city I go. Edo-Tokyo museum presents history of the city in a logical historical progression. It has all the trimmings of the museum dedicated to any city: models of palaces, recreated city dwellings, etc. The sequence goes down the history and covers daily life, arts, science, politics and religion. Nonetheless, it feels some something is constantly missing. Major plus it is pretty kid friendly, there are things for kids to do and touch. It is a good place to spend time on a bad weather day. But if you are not a museum geek, you might want to skip it.

title: A great option for a budget traveler
text: I booked this hotel on a recommendation from someone and I would like to pass it on further. It is a chain hotel and is great for a budget conscious traveler. My single room was tiny, but squeaky clean and comfortable. I loved the fact that I could operate the entire room from my bed (all the light switches are on the headboard, plus usb port, two wall jacks and environment control). Room also had a fridge and tea pot. Amenities included trouser press on the floor, microwave and vending machine (I did not use them though). Hotel does not have a restaurant, but it is located on the street full of restaurants and diners, as well as multiple markets (Lawson, 7-eleven and Family Mart), which work 24 hours and are great places to purchase drinks, snacks and some food items. Also, there is take out place by the entrance to the hotel. Hotel is conveniently located within 5-7 min walk from a subway station, which include several lines, making it easy to get to other parts of the city. There are two more APA hotels located in the vicinity: Iidabashi Ekimae (across from one of subway entrances) and Tokyo-Kudanshita (further away from the subway). I assumed that standards of service applies to all three of them. There are a lot of places one can actually walk to from the hotel.

title: Tea party at the train station
text: The restaurant is located inside shopping area of a train station and close by Keisei station (Skyliner for Narita airport). So, if you would like it could be a perfect ending of your Tokyo trip. I got there during the lunch rush, but despite hostess telling me that there were 6 parties before me, I did not wait for long. Restaurant shares a tight space with the Afternoon tea company shop, so you can totally shop while you wait. The staff was extremely pleasant, they made sure I got to the cash register faster because it was my time to be seated. I had a salad with chicken, which was to die for, freshly baked scones with cream and jam, and tea. They also have a pretty comprehensive dessert menu and I saw patrons ordering various delicious looking stuff. The prices are reasonable. If you in that area, it is definitely worth a stop.
place: Afternoon Tea Tea Room Shibuya Mark City

title: Fans only
text: The restaurant is located alongside a small amusement park in Tokyo Dome city, and is full of families. So, prepare to wait in line for some time. My wait time was almost 40 min, when I walk in about 2/3 of the tables were empty. They serve food very fast though. I had a dish which included salad, roast beef, fish and bunch of sides. I am not sure what they were, but everything was delicious. For dessert, it was a cheesecake in a mug and cafe latte with moomin design. They also had a bread station. Food was wonderful, but the main thing is moomin and unless you are a big fan, you can find equally delicious food in other places in Tokyo. Afterwards, make sure you browse a little shop for a souvenir (or two). It is also good for those travelers with younger children.
place: Moomin House Cafe Tokyo Sky Tree Town Solamachi

title: Samurai 101
text: This museum is small, but it presents a solid digest of a samurai history-culture for the tourists. They run English speaking guided tours for free. Otherwise, you can explore it on your own. They also have a presentation, which includes "ninja" and "samurai" showing off some moves with an option of taking pictures with them post-show. It might be fun for the kids. Bonus: it is in a middle of busy restaurant-bars district.

title: Best time to visit is during cherry blossoms
text: I really liked the park because I came specifically during the cherry blossoms time. Park houses a great amount of different types of cherry trees and others as well. It was a great place to mingle with locals as well, as crowds of people came in for the viewing. People were picnicking under the cherry trees and atmosphere was festive. However, without cherry blossoms, park is quite average. If you do not have much time in Tokyo, visiting it would check off several things on your sightseeing list, including different types of landscaping, emperor's old house, tea house and souvenir shopping. Also, a great place to visit for botanical gardens devotees.

title: Hits all the checks
text: This hotel gives everything one needs when traveling to Venice on a vacation. A spectacular building with great view -check; nice, clean rooms with interesting views-check; a pleasant staff-check; a good location (close to S. Marco and other landmarks) -check. They also offer a quite decent breakfast (different meats, cheese, fruits, yogurts, bread and cakes, juices, coffee and tea). If your booking does not include breakfast it is 8 euros per person and you get more for your money than in some other places in Venice. For example, we had a brioche and coffee breakfast for 5 euros elsewhere. One major con: it is 4 large flights of stairs to go to the reception and rooms. So, it might be difficult for people with mobility and or heart issues or little kids. A couple of helpful hint: when looking for hotel ask for Campo S. Maria Formosa. It is easier to locate on the map than the street Ruga Giuffa (hotel address), the entrance is on the side. If you take a water ferry from an airport get off F. te. Nove A. From there it is 15-20 min walk to the hotel (with less bridges). Overall, it was a very pleasant stay. I even liked the fact that they give old fashion keys for the room!

title: When in Venice
text: The ride on the Grand Canal is a must. You will get to see the grandeur of the city. If you can get a spot either in the middle on the small deck or in front for the best views. The back is also ok. The ferries seem to be less crowded earlier in the morning.

title: The show of wealth and power of the republic
text: If you only have one day in Venice, this is one of three things you must do there (other two are Basilica and Grand Canal ride). Designed to showcase the power and wealth of the republic to it's citizens and guests, the Doge palace manages to impress by both it's intricate decor and logical and functional construction. Everything for the Doge apartments to the Senate room. Don't miss the view of the Grand Canal out of the windows. Downside: the long line you will have to bear in order to enter. However, it is totally worth it.

title: The heart of Venice
text: This is the heart of Venice and must be seen. It is beautiful and frustrating at the same time because it is over run by people, vendors and pigeons.

title: Cross that bridge
text: It is most famous of all Venice bridges for a reason. Offers a nice photo op of itself as well as a great view of the canal. As all places in Venice is very busy with people.

title: Fantastic creation
text: Basilica S.Marco is as fantastic as they come. Rich, colorful and designed to impress churchgoers it offers all the splendors of architectural and interior designs. Take at least half an hour wondering the church. Take a look at the details. Marvel. A few notes: make sure your knees and shoulders are covered; check backpacks across the street and if you can buy "skip the line" ticket (online only) for 2 euros.

title: Chain restaurant gone good
text: This is a chain restaurant and you can see those all over the city. My friends and I had two meals in one of their locations and at least once got drinks from them (coffee). Both times we were there for breakfast. I tried crepes with sour cream (very very good) and my friends tried omelet, coffee frappe, latte, pancakes and quesadilla. We all liked our food. It is easy, cheap and pleasant way to have breakfast or lunch. The prices are quite reasonable and wait staff is pleasant. The place is always filled with locals, which is usually a good sign for a place. It is also good place for families.

title: A really nice place to have dinner after sightseeing
text: We walked in the restaurant completely randomly. It looked nice from outside and there were seats available. The menu in this restaurant is quite comprehensive and offers a different dishes, mostly from Central Asia region. We had green kutabs (a fried dough stuffed with herbs) and chebureki (fried pastry with ground beef), as well as freshly squeezed orange juice, tea and cake "Medovik" for the dessert. Everything was pretty good. The staff was polite and helpful. The prices were quite reasonable, considering that this place is literally few minutes away from the Red Square and the busiest store in town (GUM). Recommend with ease.

title: No visit to Moscow is complete without walk down Arbat
text: Arbat always has been a bohemian heart of the city. Unfortunately, nowadays it resembles many commercialized for tourist places with a plenty of souvenirs shops selling so many things and tons of restaurants full mostly of visitors. However, it still carries the signs of it's bohemian artistic nature. You can still see local artists selling their merchandise (albeit not all of it good, most of it, again, commercial), you can walk by the old buildings (wonderfully restored) that carry memories of it's inhabitants once described in a book, you can stopped by one of the most famous Russian theaters-Vahktangov theater and see Golden Turandot statue (fairly new) nearby; you can pass the statue of Bulat Okudzhava (a famous Soviet era songwriter-singer) and listen to a local poets who gather there to read their poetry to the passerby strangers; you can take a look at the statue of Pushkin and his wife at the end of the street. If you'd like you can turn into one of the little streets (pereulok) that connects Old Arbat with New Arbat (totally commercial street with tons of restaurants, bars, and high end shops) and enjoy a whiff of old Moscow charm. Overall, you definitely should visit the place, because no visit to Moscow would be complete without stop by the Arbat.

title: Good eats
text: The Old Arbat street is full of different restaurants, but you can walk into this one without hesitation. The restaurant offers Turkish cuisine, so some might hesitate. Do not. The food is really good. We tried pide with meat for an appetizer and then kebab assorted plate. My friends drank fresh orange juice and a rainbow drink (several juices mixed to look like a rainbow) and were pretty satisfied. The rainbow drink got high praise. I had a mojito (really good). For dessert we had coffees and teas. Although, if you are used for a fast service you might find service in this place a bit slow, the food is worth waiting, The restaurant atmosphere is relaxing, so you can sip your drink while waiting for food. My only problem (as always with many restaurants in Europe) is that people who smoke could be next to you. Also, the restaurant offers hookah. It has outdoor sitting though, which would allow for a fresh air and people watching while you eat.

title: One of jewels in a crown of estates around the Moscow
text: This place once belonged to one of the riches aristocratic families in Russia. The owners of estate had an unlimited resources to make their dwelling as fancy and beautiful as their hearts desired. The house, it's surroundings and fancy things inside are definitely not to be missed. The Sheremetevs (owners) were also one of the few families that owned slave artists and actors to perform in their theater. Many examples of their artwork still hangs there. It is also a place of one of the major social scandals in Russian history. In short, this place has everything: beauty, history and drama.

title: A significant piece of Russian history
text: This old church is a part of the Kremlin historical ensemble. It white washed outside walls and golden peaks shine among other equally beautiful surroundings. While the space inside is quite small (all old Russian churches are small inside) it contains beautiful frescoes, magnificent icons, and coffins of the Russian kings and princes from 12th century. The entry is free with your ticket for the Kremlin. It is worth entering and time spent. Even if you are not into history, Russian history it would still worthwhile to look at the church frescoes.

title: They always have something fun and quirky to do
text: I've been on at least 3 tours that organized by the New York Adventure Club. They always have something interesting to do. It is off beaten path and those tours are equally interesting for visitors and New Yorkers alike. Their guides are knowledgeable, prices are reasonable and all tours are well organized.

title: Walk through it
text: It is not much of an attraction, since it mostly functions as a pass between places. However, if you passing by it step in. It feels a bit surreal.

title: quintessential NYC park
text: It is a nice place to stop by while running around NY. In summer it is a place to cool off. Around Xmas they have tree. Often you get to see performers or some gatherings organized by NYU students. It provides for some cool photo ops.

title: Take it on your way to the Roosevelt Island sightseeing
text: For those who seek good photo ops of Manhattan, travel on the tramway to get bird eye picture of the city. Best time to take to avoid the crowd: midday weekday.

title: One of the best places in NY
text: Ok, Fort Tryon Park can offer you more than you'd expect from a city park. Located on the banks of the Hudson, it offers great view of the river, alleys and hidden unpaved paths. Also, they have Cloisters museum, which houses Medieval collection of art. If you are not into the art, still make a visit to gardens. While in the Fort Tryon you can easily go from a city part into a wild area, that would make you forget that you are actually in Manhattan. Worth the visit.

title: Really good service
text: It was my first time flying JAL. I heard good things about JAL and was expecting the high quality service. My expectations were met: the crew and staff were very courteous and helpful. I had to transfer in Tokyo and I mentioned that to a staff at the counter in NYC. When I landed in Tokyo, an airport staff was waiting for me to help me with the transfer (I had to go through customs, get my luggage and then re-register for a domestic flight-all within 1 hour). The food was nice and seats comfortable. I saw the crew leaving notes for passengers, who were sleeping during the food service, in case they want to eat later. A practice apparently common for JAL and ANA, but something I've never seen on any other airlines (in US, Britain, Spain, France). Considering that flight from NY is 14 hours the comfort of seats and service were very important. Overall, recommend.

title: Convenient and affordable
text: This was not my first time flying with Jetblue and it usually quite satisfactory. The seats have some extra space, we've had entertainment (live TV included), snacks were ok. On some flights they sell food, which is not bad deal, in comparison to what is being sold at the airport. However, on a shorter flights they only have snacks. Complimentary beverages were provided. Crew were nice and courteous. Overall, if I have a choice between JetBlue and other airline, I would pick JetBlue.

title: when in NY...
text: An interesting piece of NYC history and architecture. Most definite stop for the first time visitors. I would recommend finding a tour guide, who can show you nooks and crannies of the station. Avoid the rush time, visit the food court. There are also some nice shopping to be done within the walls of Grand Central.

title: Start your day in the Old City here
text: A lovely little place within the walls of the Icheri Sheher (Old City) will provide you with the nice dining experience. I came here with my friends for a breakfast. We had different omelettes (plain and with cheese), blini with meat and cheese, and tea (of course). If you are accustomed to large portions, then order more. Blini can be ordered by a count. Even though for many foreign travelers even familiar food items might look different, it tastes great. Prices are quite reasonable and staff is very friendly and polite. You have an option of sitting on a small terrace outside or go inside, which is filled with items from a bygone era (cute photo ops). Prices are reasonable and within the city average. Major notice for travelers: the service is not at the speed many foreign travelers expect and it is the norm for the country. I suggest to sit, relax, and enjoy the ambiance,while you are on vacation.

title: Where the old meets new
text: Since I grew up in this city, coming to the boulevard always brings childhood memories. It has changed though. There is an old part, that runs in two levels along side the most of the older (and central) part of the city. This part provides you with many photo ops, opportunity to walk by the sea, people watching, and tons of small cafes, that offer a variety of snacks, drinks, ice cream and food. There is a shade from old trees, that shelters you from the sun and a sea breeze, which brings a relief on a hot day. There are also carousels for kids. You can also visit a large Ferris wheel in the newer part of the boulevard in order to get a panoramic view of the city. There is also a "Little Venice", which is a small ride in artificial canals. At night, being on the boulevard will provide you with great views of the city lights. If this is your first time in Baku, visiting the Boulevard will be your quintessential Baku experience.

title: A garden that lived through times
text: For many locals and those who are returning to their birth city, this place is known as a Governor's garden (the original name, that was given to this place during the times, when Azerbaijan was part of Russian Empire). For more than a century, this place provided locals with a shade and heat relief during hot summer days and opportunities to socialize. As a tourist, you might enjoy the fact that it is close to the Old City and gives you opportunity to take a break from the sightseeing. During the past few years it underwent some renovations and adjustments, but it is still one of the most scenic and lovely spots in the city.

title: If you are passing by, the stop by
text: This is not a must see location and the monument is off the tourists' path, since it is located further within the city, where most locals live. However, it represents one of the few remaining marks of the Soviet era. Richard Sorge was an intelligence officer, who served undercover in Nazi Germany and Japan. He got information about Hitler's plan of attack on the Soviet Union, but was not believed. He also provided a vital intelligence on Japan's military plans in 1941. He was tortured and killed shortly after. The monument was erected years later, after he was awarded a Soviet Hero medal because he was born in Baku.

title: Through years and into the future
text: Those who remember old times, call it "Parapet" because a garden, that was in this location, had walls with extension. In late nineties, it was demolished and square was erected. Nowadays, it is essentially a large path between city streets. It is full of shopping and dinning places. There are a plenty of sculptures and fountains, which provide a plenty of photo ops for visitors and locals alike. If you are scheduling a meeting with someone, Fountain Square is a perfect place to do so, since it cannot be missed and is well known to everyone. If you are a fan of everything old, walk through the square towards the old buildings, which represent the first living section of the city that escaped the Old City walls.

title: Eat and eat more
text: This place represents a category of restaurants that seemed to be growing fast outside the confines of the busy city. Getting there requires a car, although a ride is about 20 minutes from the city center. Decor is a bit kitschy, but not overwhelming. There are different sitting options: from tables in the middle of the pool (elevated platforms that are surrounded by water and small fountains) to the open second floor gallery to a large room inside. The food and service were excellent. Prices are on a high average side. Beware, that if you sit outside during summer months, you might end up a pray to mosquitoes. Also, sitting outside, makes conversation difficult because of a very loud music. Music is mostly live and musicians will provide you with a healthy mix of national and more western style tunes. However, I repeat, the food was excellent! Make sure you order kebabs, including salmon ones (that one is the best), and kutabs. They also offer a variety of appetizers, which are numerous and delicious.

title: Average
text: I visited this place with a bunch of local friends for a sushi deal. According to my local friends, every Tuesday and Sunday, restaurant has deals, that allow visitors to order sets of 16 pieces for 17 az. manat or get unlimited sets for a slightly higher price. We walked in, and despite only two occupied tables, were were told that there were no space for us. After we left, a friend made a phone call and made a reservation, which allowed us to have a dinner there. It seems that restaurant management was holding spaces for reservations, although there is no indication that this restaurant is by the reservation only. The sushi were ok, but nothing special. To my taste, they were too big and had too much cream cheese in them. The server was super nice though. This place is quiet, but since it is small, the group of 6 had to squeeze in the one table. Major plus: it is no smoking restaurant.

title: A very Brooklyn ( or NY) experience
text: Park at Coney Island has been a staple in New York life for over 100 years. It still is. It is as entertaining as it is tacky, as local as it is touristy. It might be not on the top of your list if this is your first trip to NYC, but it is worth considering, especially during summer. Here is what you get at Coney Island: in addition to Luna Park with different rides for all ages, old-fashion side show, frequent street performers, original Nathan's hot dog place, tons of food stands and open area dining on the boardwalk, and the beach. By the way, with amount of small shops around, you can easily satisfy all your beach needs from the swim suits and towels to sunscreen and sand toys and Aquarium next door. Luna Park sells passes for the avid riders. The original Cyclone (Ferris wheel) is still operational. Coney Island is easily accessible via several train lines from Manhattan and Queens (although ride might be around 50 min to 1 hour). Boardwalk is busy with a mixed crowd of locals and tourists alike. On Fridays, they have fireworks in the evening. Good for families with children and teens, but not good for people who dislike crowds or lines.

title: A fair experience
text: I gave the hotel 4 stars because there were several things that I liked and a couple that I didn't. First, the room was a part of the deal with Jetblue and the room that we got, was not exactly what I expected, since in the booking it looked as there were options, when it fact there were not. I am not sure whose fault it was; hotel's or the Jetblue's. If your room on the city side and you are not used to the lights, you might feel uncomfortable. Anything that happens on the street, you will hear. The room was too small for 2 people who are not a couple. We were given a roll away bed, that barely fit in. Room was clean though. Second, the hotel (as all Hiltons) has event spaces, in 3 days we witnessed proms, conference, and a wedding. We did not hear any noise, but some people apparently did. Third, the hotel premises are small, but nice: area to sit outside a bar, hammocks under the trees, small pool and a private beach. I was told that hotel was fully booked and was worried that there would be no space in the outside areas. We waited till 4 or 5 pm to go there and spent earlier part of the day away from the hotel. There are Starbucks, bar that serves food (pretty good) and restaurant "Aqua" that is not immediately visible from the lobby. The check-in staff forgot to mention it to us. However, we ate breakfast there before our departure and it was quite good. They have hot station, selection of breads, fruits, juices, cereals, pancakes, etc. The prices at the bar and restaurant are kind of high ($14 for a mojito).There is a small shop on the hotel premises, that is opened late. It sells snacks, water, etc. Room service is served till late night (we did not use it). For cheaper breakfast options: Dunkin Donuts, McDonald's and a local restaurant across the street. The location of the hotel is quite convenient: all Nassau attractions are in a walking distance (shopping, museums, port, etc.). Jankanoo beach is in a walking distance too and fish fry restaurants are about 15 min away. It is a historic hotel, so it's location might be too tight with the city life of Nassau for some and a bit outdated in decor for others. However, overall, I must say the stay was pleasant. Hotel staff and locals alike are quite hospitable and friendly.

title: The 3.5 rating
text: The food was good, the staff was extremely nice, prices were ok. It is conveniently located by the British Colonial Hilton.

title: Spring breakers beach, according to locals
text: It is a narrow strip of sand between next to a busy road with a lot of construction on the other side of the street (hotels). I saw bunch of local small grill places on the beach, that also seemed to be selling drinks. At the end of that beach is a row of local Fish Fry restaurants. Since it is public beach, I saw people off the cruise ships and other places heading there. I don't know if it is crowded during the day, but by 5 pm it was pretty empty, with some locals hanging out on the beach and in the parked cars nearby. According to the locals, this is spring breakers beach, so I guess if you are heading to Bahamas, please check the college break schedule.

title: An interesting way to spend a couple of hours in the evening
text: We took Ghosts and Vampires tour. Our guide was entertaining and fun guy (sorry forgot his name). The tour started at the bar, which gives you a discount (two for one) on drinks if you bought tickets for the tour. It was fun walking in the evening with a drink in the hand, but the information is not that plentiful, I was kind of hoping for more. However, from my experience with the ghost tours in other cities, this is as good as it gets. We got our path crossed with a second line parade, which was an added bonus.
